title: Differential systemic decellularization in vivo to study molecular changes in each vasculature layer in murine models of disease
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Anesthesia
Timing: 30 min (for step 1)
    
Timing: 45 min
      Animals will be anesthetized using ketamine/xylazine. General anesthesia
      will be maintained alongside the DISDIVO procedure using isoflurane.
    
        Anesthesia of animals.
        
            Measure and record body weight of the animal and calculate amount of
            ketamine/xylazine at a dose of 90:10 mg/kg required.
          
            Administer the ketamine/xylazine through intraperitoneal injection
            using a 1 mL syringe with a 25-gauge needle. Intraperitoneal
            administration is injected at the lower left or right quadra of the
            mice abdomen.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
            Wait until the animal has reached a surgical plane and no tail pinch
            response is observed.
          
Place the mouse on its back on a Styrofoam dissecting tray.
            Pin the four paws of the mouse using pins or needles to accomplish
            proper immobilization of the anesthetized animal.
          
            Connect the anesthesia mask for mice (nose cone) of the isoflurane
            infuser system to the nose of the animal.
          
            Turn on the isoflurane gas to 1.5% v/v isoflurane level at a flow
            rate of 0.4–0.8 L/min.
          
Note: The use of a Styrofoam board
      positioned in a large stainless steel or autoclavable tray is highly
      recommended for collection of any possible fluid overflow (see
      Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
    
Note: animal surgical plane is generally
      accomplished in less than 5 min.
    
Note: for animal immobilization, the use
      of tape for immobilization of paws is not recommended as tape is detached
      easily if it gets in contact with liquids.
    
      Once the animal is fully anesthetized the DISDIVO procedure will start
      with the perfusion surgery. For the DISDIVO the animal is transcardially
      perfused with different buffers: i) PBS, for the detachment and collection
      of eGC;, ii) 0.5% SDC, for the ECs decellularization, lysis and
      collection; and iii) 10% SDC, for the SMCs decellularization, lysis and
      collection.
    
DISDIVO perfusion
        Perfusion surgery (see Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A–2F).

Figure 2. Surgery and initiation of the DISDIVO cardiac perfusion
            
              (A) Sterilization of the ventral fur surface with 70% ethanol.
            
(B) Cut of a patch of skin to uncover the abdominal wall.
(C) Abdominal lateral incision to open the abdominal cavity.
              (D) Cut a lateral incision at the diaphragm to expose the pleural
              cavity.
            
              (E) Opening the pleural cavity by cutting vertically along both
              sides of the ribs.
            
              (F) Flipping the ribs flap to uncover the heart and immobilizing
              the flap using halsted-mosquito hemostatic forceps.
            
              (G) Insertion of the 30-gauge needle connected to the 1× PBS
              perfusion line into the left ventricle. A blue line has been used
              to draw the heart for better interpretation, the left ventricle is
              shaded in blue.
            
              (H) Cut a small incision into the right auricle to allow drainage
              of perfusates.
            
(I) Placement of a 50 mL tube for outflow collection.
            Prepare the autoclaved surgery tools (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D–1H).
          
            Sterilize the mouse by wetting the ventral fur surface with 70%
            ethanol.
          
            Use forceps and a scissor cut a patch of skin to uncover the
            abdominal wall.
          
            Make a 2 cm lateral incision into the abdominal wall beneath the rib
            cage using forceps and scissors.
          
            Locate the diaphragm. If necessary, carefully separate the liver
            from the diaphragm.
          
            Cut the diaphragm laterally using curved blunt scissors exposing the
            pleural cavity.
          
Locate the xiphoid process, and gently lift it with forceps.
            Cut in vertical along both sides of the ribs up to the collarbone
            creating a flap. During this step carefully displace the lungs if
            necessary to avoid damaging them.
          
            Fold the created flap over the head immobilizing it using
            halsted-mosquito hemostatic forceps. If needed cut any tissue
            connecting the ribs flap to the heart.
          
        Exsanguination (see Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]G–2I).

Insert the 30-gauge needle connected to the 1× PBS perfusion line
            into the left ventricle.
          
            Turn on the syringe pump to run 1× PBS at a flow rate of 1.5 mL/min.
          
            Once perfusion has begun, rapidly create a small incision into the
            right auricle using fine scissors to allow drainage of perfusates.
            Alternatively, the collection of perfusates can be assisted by the
            injection of a 25-gauge needle into the right auricle.
          
            Place a 50 mL tube at the side of the open right auricle to collect
            blood.
          
            Change the 50 mL tube after ∼1.5 min of perfusion (almost no traces
            of blood are visible), maintain the tube containing the collected
            blood on ice and place a new 50 mL tube for the collection of the
            eGC in the next step.
          
Note: After injecting the needle of the
      perfusion line into the ventricle, it is important to not move the needle
      to ensure a proper perfusion.
    
Note: During exsanguination whole blood
      can be collected. Transferring the collected blood into tubes with the
      interior wall coated with heparin or EDTA anticoagulants is recommended,
      at the end of the procedure, if plasma will be used for further analysis.
    
Note: To reduce residual presence of blood
      components in subsequent DISDIVO fractions the perfusion with PBS in the
      exsanguination step performed at 1.5 mL/min can be prolonged, up to 3 min.
      A higher risk of eGC degradation may be observed when using long
      exsanguination times.
    
Note: blood samples obtained in this step
      can be stored during the DISDIVO procedure on ice, it is therefore
      recommended to have a box with ice during the execution of the procedure.
    
        eGC detachment and collection (DISDIVO-PBS).
        
            increase the flow rate to 2 mL/min to detach the eGC from vessel
            wall.

Perfuse the animal with 1× PBS for additional 3–4 min to completely
            collect the eGC.
          
Momentarily stop the pump.
Place the tube with the collected eGC outflow on ice.
Note: Characterization of tissues can also
      be performed by dissecting the different organs or tissues of interest
      post DISDIVO procedure. For example, characterization of the main protein
      components of the eGC remaining in the aorta tissue after DISDIVO is
      included in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A and was performed by liquid
      chromatography-based proteomics as described.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
      Images of kidney sections obtained after DISDIVO indicating disruption of
      eGC with intact ECs are also shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A. eGC
      determination by immunostaining was labeled with Alexa Fluor
      594-conjugated wheat germ agglutinin as detailed.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]

Note: In this step a higher flow rate of
      2 mL/min is used for proper eGC detachment and collection.
    
Note: the eGC outflow can be frozen at
      −80°C for further analysis but as it is not possible to stop the DISDIVO
      procedure to store samples properly, it is recommended to have a box with
      ice to keep store samples during the execution of the procedure.
    
        ECs decellularization, lysis and collection (DISDIVO-0.5% SDC).
        
            Rapidly disconnect the tubing from the 50 mL syringe filled with 1×
            PBS and connect it to the 0.5% SDC buffer filled syringe.
          
            Turn on the pump at 1.5 mL/min and collect the outflow containing
            the decellularized EC for 3–4 min.
          
Momentarily stop the pump.
            Maintain the collected EC outflow on ice until the finalization of
            the DISDIVO procedure.
          
      Immunohistochemical characterization of the EC-marker platelet and
      endothelial cell adhesion molecule 1 (PECAM1) is included in
      Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B and 3C and was performed as described in
      1.
    
Note: due to the use of detergent EC are
      lysed during the DISDIVO procedure.
    
Note: the EC outflow can be frozen at
      −80°C for further analysis but as it is not possible to stop the DISDIVO
      procedure to store samples properly, it is recommended to have a box with
      ice to keep store samples during the execution of the procedure.

SMCs decellularization, lysis and collection (DISDIVO-10% SDC).
        
            Rapidly disconnect the perfusion line from the 50 mL syringe filled
            with 0.5% SDC buffer.
          
            Place the syringe filled with 10% SDC buffer into the pump holder.
          
            Connect the perfusion line to the syringe filled with 10% SDC
            buffer.
          
            Turn on the pump at 1.5 mL/min and collect the outflow for 3–4 min.
            This collected outflow contains the decellularized SMCs.
          
Maintain the collected SMCs outflow on ice.
Note: due to the use of detergent SMCs are
      lysed during DISDIVO procedure.
    
Store all fractions at −80°C until analysis.
Critical: After completion of the
      procedure, gently flush all the tubing and rinse the tools with water to
      completely remove salts and prevent SDC deposits.
    
Note: the SMC outflow can be frozen at
      −80°C for further analysis but as it is not possible to stop the DISDIVO
      procedure to store samples properly, it is recommended to have a box with
      ice to keep store samples during the execution of the procedure.
